questions.text: Which of the following is the most frequent presentation of an abdominal desmoid tumor? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Abdominal mass

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An abdominal desmoid tumor is a tumor that arises from fibro-aponeurotic tissue in the musculoaponeurotic structures of the abdominal wall, especially below the level of the umbilicus.
  • ➤ Desmoid tumors are frequently seen to be associated with Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) syndrome.
  • ➤ It commonly presents as a slow-growing mass and tends to infiltrate muscle in the immediate area. Eventually, it can undergo a myxomatous change and then shows an increase in size more rapidly.
  • ➤ The investigation of choice for desmoid tumor is MRI. Biopsy with immunohistochemistry can help in establishing the diagnosis. The tumors typically stain positive for
  • ➤ 3-catenin Actin and Vimentin.
  • ➤ 3-catenin
  • ➤ Actin and
  • ➤ Vimentin.
  • ➤ It stains negative for cytokeratin and S-100.
  • ➤ Treatment includes wide excision with a margin clearance of 2.5cm to avoid recurrence. It is a completely unencapsulated fibroma and is hard to cut. The defect then requires repair using mesh to prevent hernia in the future. Radiotherapy alone is an acceptable treatment option for patients with unresectable desmoid tumors Prognosis is good, with no metastasis or sarcomatous change. Although they lack metastatic potential, they can be multifocal as well as locally aggressive and invasive, with a high propensity for recurrence.
  • ➤ Treatment includes wide excision with a margin clearance of 2.5cm to avoid recurrence. It is a completely unencapsulated fibroma and is hard to cut. The defect then requires repair using mesh to prevent hernia in the future.
  • ➤ Radiotherapy alone is an acceptable treatment option for patients with unresectable desmoid tumors
  • ➤ Prognosis is good, with no metastasis or sarcomatous change. Although they lack metastatic potential, they can be multifocal as well as locally aggressive and invasive, with a high propensity for recurrence.

questions.text: Which is the most common Osteoporotic fracture site? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vertebral fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common site for osteoporotic fractures is the vertebral column followed by femur (mainly neck) and lower end of the radius.
  • ➤ The most common site for osteoporotic fractures is the vertebral column followed by femur (mainly neck) and lower end of the radius.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of progressively worsening fatigue, night sweats, and painless lymph node swelling. She reports unintentional weight loss and occasional low-grade fevers. Physical examination reveals multiple, firm, non-tender lymph nodes in the cervical, axillary, and inguinal regions. Laboratory tests show mild anemia with normal white blood cell and platelet counts. Imaging reveals generalized lymphadenopathy without splenomegaly. A bone marrow aspiration is planned to evaluate for potential marrow involvement, but the clinician is concerned about the possibility of a dry tap. Which of the following conditions is least likely to result in a dry tap during a bone marrow aspiration?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A dry tap during bone marrow aspiration occurs when the aspiration needle fails to retrieve adequate marrow cells.
  • • Follicular lymphoma, while it can involve the bone marrow, typically infiltrates in a less disruptive manner. It doesn't cause extensive fibrosis or significantly alter the marrow architecture, allowing for successful aspiration in most cases.
  • • Causes of dry tap are:
  • • Causes of dry tap are:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. AML-M7 (Acute Megakaryoblastic Leukemia): Megakaryoblasts in this subtype often stimulate marrow fibrosis, leading to dry taps.
  • • Option A. AML-M7 (Acute Megakaryoblastic Leukemia):
  • • Option B. CML (Chronic Myeloid Leukemia): In advanced stages, CML can progress to a fibrotic phase, making aspiration difficult.
  • • Option B. CML (Chronic Myeloid Leukemia):
  • • Option C. Myelofibrosis: This condition is characterized by extensive marrow fibrosis, making dry taps a hallmark feature.
  • • Option C. Myelofibrosis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Causes of dry tap are:
  • ➤ Causes of dry tap are:
  • ➤ Faulty technique Metastatic carcinoma infiltration Chronic myeloid leukemia Myelofibrosis Hairy cell leukemia Acute leukemia Hodgkin's lymphoma AML- M7
  • ➤ Faulty technique
  • ➤ Metastatic carcinoma infiltration
  • ➤ Chronic myeloid leukemia
  • ➤ Myelofibrosis
  • ➤ Hairy cell leukemia
  • ➤ Acute leukemia
  • ➤ Hodgkin's lymphoma
  • ➤ AML- M7

questions.text: What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Pseudoexfoliation syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is characterized by the deposition of amorphous grey dandruff-like material on various parts of the eye, leading to potential complications like secondary open-angle glaucoma.

questions.text: A 62-year-old presented with diminished vision 1 year after cataract surgery. The findings are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? ( AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) After cataract

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Posterior capsular opacification or after cataract is a common post-surgical complication following cataract surgery, characterized by the proliferation of lens epithelial cells leading to opacification of the posterior capsule. This can diminish vision and may require further treatment, typically a simple laser procedure called a YAG capsulotomy to restore clarity to the visual axis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of puberty menorrhagia? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anovulation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Anovulation is the most common cause of puberty menorrhagia. Menorrhagia refers to heavy menstrual bleeding that occurs in a regular cycle. In adolescents, anovulation, which is the failure of the ovary to release an oocyte during a menstrual cycle, frequently leads to heavy or prolonged bleeding due to the lack of a normal hormonal cycle that regulates the endometrial lining. Without the usual cyclical hormonal fluctuations, the endometrial lining may become excessively thick, leading to heavy bleeding when it sheds. This condition is typical in puberty due to the body's ongoing adjustment to hormonal regulation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Endometriosis : Endometriosis involves the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus, which can cause painful menstruation and potentially contribute to menorrhagia. However, it is less common than anovulation as the primary cause of menorrhagia in adolescents.
  • • Option B. Endometriosis
  • • Option C. Malignancy : Malignancy is a rare cause of menorrhagia in puberty. While malignancy can lead to abnormal bleeding, it is not the most common cause in this age group.
  • • Option C. Malignancy
  • • Option D. Bleeding disorder : Bleeding disorders such as von Willebrand disease or hemophilia can cause menorrhagia but are less common compared to anovulation in adolescents.
  • • Option D. Bleeding disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anovulation is the most common cause of menorrhagia in puberty.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with spinal TB; he has a swelling in the left groin with limb attitude is in flexion. Identify what caused it? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. A

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given clinical scenario of a patient with Pott spine having persistent hip flexion with a history of spinal tuberculosis is suggestive of psoas abscess involving the psoas muscle , marked A in the given coronal CT image.
  • • Pott spine
  • • having persistent hip flexion
  • • psoas abscess
  • • involving the psoas muscle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with spinal TB, a psoas abscess is a significant complication that can lead to symptoms such as groin swelling and changes in limb posture due to its location and the effect of the abscess on the surrounding structures, particularly the psoas muscle. Prompt recognition and treatment are crucial to manage symptoms and prevent further complications.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can cause flagellated pigmentation of skin? ( AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Bleomycin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bleomycin is known to cause flagellated hyperpigmentation of the skin as a unique side effect. It can also cause pulmonary fibrosis, making it important to monitor patients for respiratory symptoms during treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following activate glycogen phosphorylase? ( INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation: Calcium ions play a role in the activation of glycogen phosphorylase. When there is a need for energy, an increase in intracellular calcium levels can activate glycogen phosphorylase. Calcium ions bind to calmodulin, which, in turn, activates phosphorylase kinase. Phosphorylase kinase then phosphorylates and activates glycogen phosphorylase.
  • • Explanation:
  • • Relevance: Calcium-mediated activation of glycogen phosphorylase is part of the fight-or-flight response, ensuring a rapid release of glucose for energy during periods of stress or physical activity.
  • • Relevance:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Glucose 6-Phosphate:
  • • Option B.
  • • Glucose 6-Phosphate:
  • • Explanation: Glucose 6-phosphate is a product of the glycolytic pathway and is an indicator of sufficient energy within the cell. High levels of glucose 6-phosphate inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. Glycogen phosphorylase is typically activated when glucose levels are low and energy demand is high. Relevance: The presence of glucose 6-phosphate signals that the cell has adequate energy reserves and does not need to break down glycogen.
  • • Explanation: Glucose 6-phosphate is a product of the glycolytic pathway and is an indicator of sufficient energy within the cell. High levels of glucose 6-phosphate inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. Glycogen phosphorylase is typically activated when glucose levels are low and energy demand is high.
  • • Explanation:
  • • Relevance: The presence of glucose 6-phosphate signals that the cell has adequate energy reserves and does not need to break down glycogen.
  • • Relevance:
  • • Option C. Glucose:
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Glucose:
  • • Explanation: Glucose itself does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. In fact, high levels of glucose can have an inhibitory effect on glycogen phosphorylase because it indicates that there is sufficient glucose available for energy needs, reducing the need to break down glycogen. Relevance: Elevated glucose levels signal that there is no immediate need to activate glycogen phosphorylase.
  • • Explanation: Glucose itself does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. In fact, high levels of glucose can have an inhibitory effect on glycogen phosphorylase because it indicates that there is sufficient glucose available for energy needs, reducing the need to break down glycogen.
  • • Explanation:
  • • Relevance: Elevated glucose levels signal that there is no immediate need to activate glycogen phosphorylase.
  • • Relevance:
  • • Option D. High ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate):
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • High ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate):
  • • Explanation: High levels of ATP can inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. ATP is a molecule that stores energy, and when ATP levels are high, it indicates that the cell has sufficient energy reserves. In this context, glycogen phosphorylase would not be activated to break down glycogen. Relevance: High ATP levels signal that there is no immediate need for additional energy from glycogenolysis.
  • • Explanation: High levels of ATP can inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. ATP is a molecule that stores energy, and when ATP levels are high, it indicates that the cell has sufficient energy reserves. In this context, glycogen phosphorylase would not be activated to break down glycogen.
  • • Explanation:
  • • Relevance: High ATP levels signal that there is no immediate need for additional energy from glycogenolysis.
  • • Relevance:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glycogen Phosphorylase is first and RLE of glycogenolysis. It transfers P i , uses PLP (B 6 ) and breaks α (1 à 4) bonds from one end until 4 glucose residues are left at branch point. End-product is Glucose 1–P (90%). It exists in two forms b and a. which is regulated by various mechanism shown as:

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with chronic liver disease is experiencing recurrent urinary tract infections. His healthcare team is considering various antibiotics, including fluoroquinolones, to treat the infection. Which of the following fluoroquinolones is not recommended for use in patients with liver disease? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pefloxacin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fluoroquinolones that are safe in renal failure, avoided in liver failure and not effective in UTI include:
  • ➤ P: Pefloxacin M: Moxifloxacin T: Trovafloxacin
  • ➤ P: Pefloxacin
  • ➤ M: Moxifloxacin
  • ➤ T: Trovafloxacin

questions.text: Following a road traffic accident, a 58-year-old man with multiple lower limb fractures and lung contusion was brought to the hospital, where he later died. An autopsy lung biopsy revealed certain features. What is the most likely cause of his death? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A traumatic accident that resulted in extensive fractures, particularly in the long bones of the lower limbs, which predisposes to fat embolism. This condition typically occurs when bone marrow fat is mobilized into the bloodstream following a fracture, blocking pulmonary vasculature. Histopathological findings from the lung biopsy likely included the presence of fat globules in pulmonary vessels, a hallmark of fat embolism syndrome (FES). This syndrome is a known complication of such injuries and aligns with the clinical context and autopsy findings.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Emphysema: This is a chronic condition leading to airspace enlargement and does not occur acutely due to trauma. Option B. Congestive heart failure: While it can cause pulmonary edema, it is unlikely to acutely result from trauma unless there was a cardiac injury, which is not indicated in this scenario. Option D. Pulmonary embolism: Typically involves a clot from the deep veins (thromboembolism), not fat from fractures, and would show different histopathological features.
  • • Option A. Emphysema: This is a chronic condition leading to airspace enlargement and does not occur acutely due to trauma.
  • • Option A. Emphysema:
  • • Option B. Congestive heart failure: While it can cause pulmonary edema, it is unlikely to acutely result from trauma unless there was a cardiac injury, which is not indicated in this scenario.
  • • Option B. Congestive heart failure:
  • • Option D. Pulmonary embolism: Typically involves a clot from the deep veins (thromboembolism), not fat from fractures, and would show different histopathological features.
  • • Option D. Pulmonary embolism:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the causative agent for Hooch tragedy? ( INICET MAY 2022 )
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Methanol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hooch tragedies occur due to the consumption of illicitly brewed liquor contaminated with methanol, a toxic form of alcohol that can cause severe health effects including death.

questions.text: Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which did not subside even after 3 weeks of birth, was observed in a neonate. On investigating, liver enzymes, PT/INR and albumin levels were normal. No hemolysis was seen on a peripheral blood smear. A drop in bilirubin level was observed within a week after treatment with phenobarbital. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Crigler Najjar type 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Crigler-Najjar type 2 presents with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that responds to phenobarbital, distinguishing it from other forms of hereditary hyperbilirubinemia.

Ans. B) Ordinal

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents to the emergency department with worsening shortness of breath, persistent dry cough, and high fever for the past 8 days. He complains of severe fatigue and difficulty breathing even while resting. On examination, his temperature is 102°F (38.9°C), and his oxygen saturation is 80% on room air. Lung auscultation reveals diffuse bilateral crackles. Chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates, and CT imaging confirms findings suggestive of severe COVID-19 pneumonia. Despite receiving supplemental oxygen, his condition rapidly deteriorates, and he requires intubation. Based on the most common lung pathology associated with severe COVID-19 infection, what is the primary lung abnormality observed?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Diffuse Alveolar Damage (DAD) is the predominant lung pathology seen in severe COVID-19 pneumonia, particularly in those requiring intensive care or mechanical ventilation. It represents an acute injury to the lung parenchyma, leading to severe impairment of gas exchange.
  • • Diffuse Alveolar Damage (DAD)
  • • Histopathological Features of DAD in COVID-19:
  • • Histopathological Features of DAD in COVID-19:
  • • Early Phase (Exudative):
  • • Early Phase (Exudative):
  • • Intra-alveolar edema (fluid accumulation) Endothelial cell necrosis (damage to the lining of blood vessels) Microthrombosis (formation of small blood clots within vessels) Endothelialitis (inflammation of blood vessel lining)
  • • Intra-alveolar edema (fluid accumulation)
  • • Endothelial cell necrosis (damage to the lining of blood vessels)
  • • Microthrombosis (formation of small blood clots within vessels)
  • • Endothelialitis (inflammation of blood vessel lining)
  • • Later Phase (Proliferative):
  • • Later Phase (Proliferative):
  • • Pneumocyte type 2 hyperplasia (increased number of cells responsible for surfactant production) Intra-alveolar giant cells (abnormal large cells) Hyaline membrane formation (protein-rich deposits lining alveoli) Solid fibrin deposits (protein involved in blood clotting) Thrombosis in small to medium-sized vessels
  • • Pneumocyte type 2 hyperplasia (increased number of cells responsible for surfactant production)
  • • Intra-alveolar giant cells (abnormal large cells)
  • • Hyaline membrane formation (protein-rich deposits lining alveoli)
  • • Solid fibrin deposits (protein involved in blood clotting)
  • • Thrombosis in small to medium-sized vessels
  • • Clinical Impact
  • • Clinical Impact
  • • These changes result in a breakdown of the alveolar-capillary barrier, hindering oxygen transfer to the blood and causing severe hypoxemia (low blood oxygen levels). This manifests as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), a life-threatening condition often seen in severe COVID-19.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Pulmonary abscess: A localized collection of pus within the lung, often caused by bacterial infection. While possible in COVID-19, it's not the primary pathology and doesn't explain the diffuse lung involvement.
  • • Option B. Pulmonary abscess:
  • • Option C. Bronchiolitis obliterans: A chronic inflammatory condition leading to small airway obstruction. It's not typically associated with acute COVID-19 pneumonia.
  • • Option C. Bronchiolitis obliterans:
  • • Option D. Interstitial lung disease: A group of conditions causing lung scarring. While COVID-19 can lead to long-term lung damage, the acute presentation is dominated by DAD.
  • • Option D. Interstitial lung disease:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diffuse alveolar damage is the hallmark of severe COVID-19 lung injury, leading to ARDS and significant morbidity and mortality. Recognizing its key features helps understand the pathophysiology and clinical manifestations of severe COVID-19 pneumonia.

questions.text: A patient presented with painless decrease in vision and metamorphopsia. Fundus examination revealed the lesion shown in the image. What is the expected finding on ultrasonography? ( AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When diagnosing choroidal melanoma via ultrasonography, the "collar stud appearance" is a key finding. Recognizing this feature, along with the clinical presentation of painless visual loss and metamorphopsia, supports a timely and accurate diagnosis of this potentially life-threatening condition.

questions.text: Identify the correct 'organism-drug to which it is intrinsically resistant' pair: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Candida Krusei is intrinsically resistant to fluconazole.

questions.text: A young patient began taking a weight loss medication that works by preventing fat absorption from food. She developed easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding after a few weeks. Which of the following vitamins deficiency is likely to be responsible for her condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vitamin K

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin K deficiency due to impaired fat absorption from weight loss medications can lead to bleeding manifestations such as easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female with bleeding disorder, gives family history of her father and sister suffering from the same bleeding disorders. Which is the most likely disorder? ( INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Von Willebrand disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Von Willebrand disease is characterized by its autosomal dominant inheritance pattern and affects both genders, making it the most likely diagnosis for a female patient with a family history of bleeding disorders involving both male and female family members.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with painful blisters on the skin and oral mucosa. Direct immunofluorescence is given below. Which of the following is false regarding the same? (AIIMS MAY 2017)

options.label: C
options.text: Suprabasal acantholytic blister is a characteristic feature

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Antibiotics against hemidesmosomes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pemphigus vulgaris is characterized by autoantibodies against desmosomal proteins (desmoglein 1 and 3), leading to a suprabasal acantholytic blister and a diagnostic fish-net appearance on direct immunofluorescence.

questions.text: You are a global health researcher working on a report assessing the development status of various countries. To classify the countries and compare them, you decide to use the Human Development Index (HDI). You recall that HDI is a commonly utilized measure but seek to clarify its exact components, as presented by organizations like the World Health Organization (WHO). Which of the following correctly identifies the components that make up the HDI? (INICET NOV 2021)

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and standard of living

options.label: C
options.text: Infant mortality rate, literacy and standard of living

options.label: D
options.text: Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and infant mortality rate

questions.correct_answer: A. Life expectancy at birth, literacy and standard of living
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Life expectancy at birth, literacy and standard of living

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the endocrinology clinic with complaints of progressive changes in his physical appearance over the past five years. He notes that his hands and feet have grown larger, requiring new shoes and rings, and his facial features have become coarser, with an especially prominent jaw. He also reports increased sweating, frequent headaches, joint pain, and occasional blurred vision. On examination, he has enlarged hands with thickened, sausage-like fingers, a broad lower face, and a protruding jaw (mandibular prognathism). Laboratory evaluation reveals elevated levels of growth hormone (GH) and insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1). MRI of the brain shows a pituitary mass consistent with an adenoma. Based on the clinical presentation and findings, which gene is most likely implicated in this patient’s condition?

options.label: D
options.text: PRKAR1A (Protein Kinase A Regulatory Subunit 1 Alpha)

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Mutations in the PIT1 (POU1F1) gene, a pituitary-specific transcription factor, can lead to the development of somatotroph adenomas that produce excessive growth hormone (GH). Elevated GH levels result in increased production of insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1), which is responsible for the characteristic features of acromegaly when these hormones are overproduced after the closure of growth plates. Acromegaly manifests with overgrowth of the skin, soft tissues, and viscera, including the thyroid, heart, and liver. The bones of the face, hands, and feet become thickened and enlarged, leading to a distinct appearance with prognathism and broadening of the lower face. Additional systemic complications include hypertension, diabetes mellitus, arthritis, and an increased risk of cardiovascular and gastrointestinal diseases.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. MEN1 (Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1)
  • • Option B. MEN1 (Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1)
  • • MEN1 gene mutations cause a syndrome involving multiple endocrine tumors, including those in the parathyroid glands, pancreas, and pituitary. Although pituitary adenomas can occur, they do not specifically explain the isolated somatotroph adenoma or the distinct acromegaly features linked to PIT1 dysregulation.
  • • Option C. GHRHR (Growth Hormone-Releasing Hormone Receptor)
  • • Option C. GHRHR (Growth Hormone-Releasing Hormone Receptor)
  • • Mutations in GHRHR can affect growth hormone regulation but typically do not lead to the development of somatotroph adenomas or the acromegaly features seen in this patient. GHRHR mutations often result in isolated growth hormone deficiency rather than hormone excess.
  • • Option D. PRKAR1A (Protein Kinase A Regulatory Subunit 1 Alpha)
  • • Option D. PRKAR1A (Protein Kinase A Regulatory Subunit 1 Alpha)
  • • PRKAR1A mutations are associated with Carney complex, a condition involving spotty skin pigmentation, myxomas, and endocrine overactivity, including pituitary tumors. However, it does not specifically cause isolated somatotroph adenomas or the classic findings of acromegaly as seen with PIT1 mutations.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PIT1 (POU1F1) is a critical transcription factor for pituitary somatotroph, lactotroph, and thyrotroph cells. Mutations in PIT1 can lead to pituitary adenomas that secrete excessive growth hormone, resulting in acromegaly characterized by enlarged extremities, coarse facial features, and other systemic complications such as hypertension, diabetes, and increased cardiovascular risk. Recognizing these features is essential for early diagnosis and targeted management of acromegaly.

questions.text: Which of the following marked structures does not form part of the laryngeal skeleton? ( INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. A

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The structure marked as 'A', is the hyoid bone, which is not a part of the laryngeal skeleton.
  • • The hyoid bone is a U-shaped bone located at the base of the tongue. While it is not considered a part of the larynx itself, it is closely associated with the larynx and serves as an attachment point for several laryngeal muscles
  • • The structures marked in the image are:
  • • The structures marked in the image are:
  • • Hyoid bone Thyroid cartilage Epiglottis Cricoid cartilage
  • • Hyoid bone
  • • Thyroid cartilage
  • • Epiglottis
  • • Cricoid cartilage
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B . Thyroid Cartilage: The thyroid cartilage is a large, shield-shaped cartilage in the larynx. It forms the prominent Adam's apple in the front of the neck and plays a role in sound production.
  • • Option B
  • • Thyroid Cartilage:
  • • Option C. Epiglottis: The epiglottis is a leaf-shaped cartilage located at the base of the tongue. Its primary function is to prevent food and liquids from entering the airway (trachea) during swallowing.
  • • Option C.
  • • Epiglottis:
  • • Option D. Cricoid Cartilage: The cricoid cartilage is a ring-shaped cartilage located just below the thyroid cartilage. It is the only complete ring of cartilage in the larynx and provides structural support to the airway.
  • • Option D.
  • • Cricoid Cartilage:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A set of cartilages that are joined by ligaments and fibrous membranes make up the laryngeal skeleton:
  • ➤ Hyaline cartilage : The thyroid, cricoid, and the greater part of the arytenoid cartilages Elastic cartilage : The corniculate, cuneiform, tritiate, and epiglottic cartilages and the apices of the arytenoid cartilage.
  • ➤ Hyaline cartilage : The thyroid, cricoid, and the greater part of the arytenoid cartilages
  • ➤ Hyaline cartilage
  • ➤ Elastic cartilage : The corniculate, cuneiform, tritiate, and epiglottic cartilages and the apices of the arytenoid cartilage.
  • ➤ Elastic cartilage

questions.text: Which of these is the most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Insulinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Insulinoma is the most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas, arising from beta cells and frequently causing hypoglycemia due to excessive insulin production.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female presented in December with chronic fatigue, cyanosis of the nose, blue lips, and arthralgia. A peripheral blood smear is provided. What is the most likely cause of these findings? (AIIMS NOV 2016)

options.label: A
options.text: Clumps of RBCs due to IgG mediated cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia

options.label: B
options.text: Clumps of RBCs due to IgM mediated cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia

options.label: D
options.text: Clumps of RBCs due to IgG mediated warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia

questions.correct_answer: B. Clumps of RBCs due to IgM mediated cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. IgG mediated cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia: This option is incorrect because IgG antibodies are usually associated with warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia, not cold. Option C. RBC lysis due to hemoglobinopathy: Hemoglobinopathies typically cause morphological abnormalities in RBCs, not agglutination. Option D. Clumps of RBCs due to IgG mediated warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia: This condition involves IgG antibodies that act at body temperature and do not cause symptoms that worsen with cold exposure.
  • • Option A. IgG mediated cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia: This option is incorrect because IgG antibodies are usually associated with warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia, not cold.
  • • Option A. IgG mediated cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia:
  • • Option C. RBC lysis due to hemoglobinopathy: Hemoglobinopathies typically cause morphological abnormalities in RBCs, not agglutination.
  • • Option C. RBC lysis due to hemoglobinopathy:
  • • Option D. Clumps of RBCs due to IgG mediated warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia: This condition involves IgG antibodies that act at body temperature and do not cause symptoms that worsen with cold exposure.
  • • Option D. Clumps of RBCs due to IgG mediated warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:

questions.text: Which of the following STD is transmitted by all components of the blood? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Syphilis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, is an STD that can be transmitted by all components of the blood, highlighting the importance of thorough blood screening.

questions.text: Which parameters would you utilize to assess the efficiency of the malaria surveillance system under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programmer? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Annual Blood Examination Rate

questions.text: A patient complains of persistent, dull, aching pain in both legs. He reports a history of extended periods of standing and mentions having visibly twisted veins in his legs. What tests would typically be conducted to assess saphenofemoral incompetence in this scenario? ( INICET MAY 2023) Brodie Trendelenburg Test Morrissey's test Fegan's test Modified Perthes test
questions.explanation: Ans. C) 1, 2

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient with a midline neck swelling and histopathological findings of Orphan Annie eye nuclei on biopsy as shown below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Papillary carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of Orphan Annie eye nuclei on histopathological examination is a key diagnostic feature of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

questions.text: Identify this instrument used in laparoscopic surgery? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Veress needle

questions.text: You're a physician attending a conference on emerging infectious diseases. As the discussion shifts towards the recent outbreaks in South India, the speaker displays an image showcasing the life cycle of a specific virus. A fellow physician sitting beside you, being relatively unfamiliar with the recent disease trends in South India, asks for your insights about the virus in question. Given the depicted life cycle and the associated clinical syndromes, which of the following viruses would be the most likely culprit? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Nipah virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nipah virus, transmitted through fruit bats and causing encephalitis, fits the transmission cycle shown in the image and is a significant emerging infectious disease in regions such as Malaysia and Bangladesh.
  • ➤ Nipah virus, transmitted through fruit bats and causing encephalitis, fits the transmission cycle shown in the image and is a significant emerging infectious disease in regions such as Malaysia and Bangladesh.

questions.text: A child presented with bilateral proptosis. From the peripheral smear, he was suspected to have chloroma. What is the next investigation of choice? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bone marrow examination

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For suspected chloroma in the context of AML, a bone marrow examination is the critical next step to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment.
  • ➤ chloroma
  • ➤ bone marrow examination
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1150-1154
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1150-1154

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department with. He also reports night sweats and significant unintentional weight loss.. Serum tumor markers, including alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG), are elevated. A biopsy confirms an extragonadal germ cell tumor. What is the most common site for an extragonadal germ cell tumor?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The mediastinum is the most common site for extragonadal germ cell tumors, accounting for 50-70% of these cases, particularly in young males. These tumors develop from ectopic germ cells that fail to migrate correctly during embryogenesis and become trapped in the mediastinum, where they can proliferate. Symptoms often include chest pain, cough, and dyspnea due to the mass effect, along with systemic symptoms like night sweats and weight loss. The presence of elevated serum tumor markers such as AFP and β-hCG aids in diagnosis, confirmed by imaging and biopsy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Liver
  • • Option A. Liver
  • • The liver is not a common primary site for extragonadal germ cell tumors. Tumors found in the liver are typically metastatic rather than primary extragonadal germ cell tumors, making it an unlikely location for this diagnosis.
  • • Option B. Adrenal glands
  • • Option B. Adrenal glands
  • • The adrenal glands are not a typical site for extragonadal germ cell tumors. Tumors in the adrenal region are more likely to be adrenal adenomas, pheochromocytomas, or metastatic lesions rather than primary germ cell tumors.
  • • Option C. Paraspinal region
  • • Option C. Paraspinal region
  • • While paraspinal masses can occur, they are more commonly neurogenic tumors, such as schwannomas or neuroblastomas, rather than extragonadal germ cell tumors. Germ cell tumors in this area are rare compared to the mediastinum.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The mediastinum is the most common site for extragonadal germ cell tumors, accounting for 50-70% of cases, particularly in young males. These tumors arise due to misplaced germ cells during embryogenesis and often present with symptoms related to the mass effect, such as chest pain, cough, and dyspnea, alongside elevated tumor markers like AFP and β-hCG. Recognizing the mediastinum as the primary site is essential for proper diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient on medication presents with the lab values as shown below. ( INICET MAY 2022) Which of the following drugs should be stopped? K + :6.5 meg/L Na + :137 meg/L Urea: 42 mg/dL Creatinine: 3.8 mg/dL
questions.explanation:
Ans.  C. Losartan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a hypertensive patient with hyperkalemia and impaired kidney function, Losartan should be stopped due to its potential to exacerbate hyperkalemia. Amlodipine, hydrochlorothiazide, and furosemide do not typically increase potassium levels and do not need to be stopped. In fact, furosemide may help in lowering the elevated potassium levels.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl presents with a midline neck swelling that moves on deglutition. Ultrasound revealed a 2 cm x 2 cm nodule on the left lobe of the thyroid, extending into the strap muscles. The histopathology image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Papillary cancer of thyroid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is characterized by Orphan Annie nuclei, psammoma bodies, and a papillary architecture, which are key diagnostic features.

questions.text: Predominantly osteoblastic secondaries are seen in: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Prostate carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osteoblastic metastases are a hallmark of prostate carcinoma, unlike breast and stomach carcinomas which are more likely to cause osteolytic or no bone lesions respectively.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are associated with Neurosecretory bodies except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Adrenal cortical tumor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neurosecretory bodies are associated with neuroendocrine tumors, but not with adrenal cortical tumors, which originate from the adrenal cortex and are involved in steroid hormone production.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about celiac disease? (AIIMS MAY 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Most common cause of malnutrition in developing countries

options.label: C
options.text: Improves with food rich in carbohydrates

questions.correct_answer: D. Increased risk of GI lymphoma
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Increased risk of GI lymphoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Celiac disease is associated with an increased risk of gastrointestinal lymphoma, specifically enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma, making it a critical long-term concern for individuals with this condition.
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg 1518-1519
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition pg 1518-1519

questions.text: By which cell of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma arises? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Naive B cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma arises from naive B cells or post-germinal center memory B cells, distinguishing it from other B-cell and T-cell malignancies.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an intermediate filament? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tubulin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tubulin is not an intermediate filament; it is a protein that forms microtubules, which are essential for cell shape, motility, and division. Intermediate filaments, such as vimentin, desmin, and neurofilaments, provide mechanical support and structural integrity to cells.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true regarding sirtuins? (INICET NOV 2022) Increases insulin sensitivity and thus glucose metabolism. Promotes genes that increase longevity. They are of 7 types. They are one of the types of histone deacetylases.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sirtuins are a family of seven histone deacetylases involved in increasing insulin sensitivity, glucose metabolism, promoting genes associated with longevity, and playing a significant role in various cellular processes.
  • ➤ Sirtuins

questions.text: Which of the following are the features of the color of normal amniotic fluid during? (INICET NOV 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Milky to yellowish green with mucus flakes

questions.correct_answer: C. Clear colorless to pale yellow
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Clear colorless to pale yellow

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The color of normal amniotic fluid varies during pregnancy and can indicate different conditions:
  • • In early pregnancy: The amniotic fluid is colorless. Near term: It becomes straw-colored. Deep yellow/golden color: This can indicate fetal anemia. Green (meconium-stained): Indicates fetal distress or post-maturity. Red: Suggests abruption. Dark colored/tobacco-like: Indicates fetal demise.
  • • In early pregnancy: The amniotic fluid is colorless.
  • • In early pregnancy:
  • • Near term: It becomes straw-colored.
  • • Near term:
  • • Deep yellow/golden color: This can indicate fetal anemia.
  • • Deep yellow/golden color:
  • • Green (meconium-stained): Indicates fetal distress or post-maturity.
  • • Green (meconium-stained):
  • • Red: Suggests abruption.
  • • Red:
  • • Dark colored/tobacco-like: Indicates fetal demise.
  • • Dark colored/tobacco-like:
  • • Normal amniotic fluid should be clear, colorless, or pale yellow, especially in the earlier stages of pregnancy and near term when the fluid changes to a straw color.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Milky to yellowish green with mucus flakes: This description is not characteristic of normal amniotic fluid. Such a color can indicate the presence of infection or contamination.
  • • Option A. Milky to yellowish green with mucus flakes:
  • • Option B. Amber colored: Amber-colored amniotic fluid is not a normal finding and may indicate complications such as the presence of blood or other abnormalities.
  • • Option B. Amber colored:
  • • Option D. Golden color: Golden-colored amniotic fluid typically indicates fetal anemia, which is a pathological condition and not a feature of normal amniotic fluid.
  • • Option D. Golden color:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Normal amniotic fluid is clear, colorless to pale yellow, changing to straw-colored near term.
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Pg 43, William’s text book of obstetrics 24th edition pg 298
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Pg 43, William’s text book of obstetrics 24th edition pg 298

questions.text: Which of the following bands will increase in serum electrophoresis in Nephrotic syndrome? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Alpha 2 globulin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In Nephrotic syndrome, Alpha 2 globulin increases on serum electrophoresis as a response to heavy proteinuria, while albumin significantly decreases leading to symptoms such as severe swelling and fluid accumulation in the body.

  • ➤ The drug most likely implicated in causing malignant hyperthermia in the given scenario is suxamethonium (succinylcholine) because it is known to trigger this condition in susceptible individuals.

questions.explanation:
Ans.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters are included in qSOFA score? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) SBP, RR, GCS score

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The qSOFA score includes three clinical criteria: respiratory rate (RR) ≥ 22/min, systolic blood pressure (SBP) ≤ 100 mmHg, and altered mental status (GCS score). A qSOFA score of ≥2 indicates a higher risk of poor outcomes in patients with suspected infection.
  • ➤ The qSOFA score includes three clinical criteria: respiratory rate (RR) ≥ 22/min, systolic blood pressure (SBP) ≤ 100 mmHg, and altered mental status (GCS score).
  • ➤ A qSOFA score of ≥2 indicates a higher risk of poor outcomes in patients with suspected infection.

questions.text: What does the following image show? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Emperipolesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Emperipolesis is a unique process where one cell enters another without being destroyed, differentiating it from phagocytosis and entosis, with the host cell usually being a megakaryocyte or histiocyte .
  • ➤ Emperipolesis
  • ➤ megakaryocyte
  • ➤ histiocyte

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presented with cough, fatigability, and weight loss. He was diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) on bronchoscopy. The resected specimen had a hilar lymph node that was 1cm in size and showed a black pigment. What is the black pigment likely to be? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anthracotic pigment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anthracotic pigment, resulting from the deposition of carbon particles, is the most likely cause of the black pigment observed in the hilar lymph node of a patient with squamous cell carcinoma. This is common in individuals exposed to high levels of environmental pollution or occupational hazards involving carbon particles.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents to the clinic with a two-month history of intermittent fever, significant weight loss, night sweats, and abdominal discomfort. Physical examination reveals splenomegaly and pallor. Laboratory investigations show pancytopenia, leading the physician to suspect visceral leishmaniasis. To confirm the diagnosis, a blood smear is prepared and stained using Leishman stain. During the staining process, the physician explains to a medical student the use of acetone-free methanol in the procedure. The student is curious about its specific role in the staining process. What role does acetone-free methanol play in this staining process?

options.label: B
options.text: Stains the DNA of the parasite

questions.correct_answer: A. Fixes cells to the slide
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Acetone-free methanol is used in Leishman stains primarily to fix cells to the slide. Fixation is a crucial step in preparing blood smears as it preserves the cellular architecture by denaturing proteins and adhering cells, including parasites, firmly to the slide. This fixation prevents the cells from washing away during subsequent staining steps and maintains their morphology, allowing for accurate visualization under the microscope. Using acetone-free methanol specifically avoids the dehydration and distortion that acetone-containing fixatives might cause, ensuring the cells remain intact and identifiable during the diagnostic process.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Stains the DNA of the parasite
  • • Option B. Stains the DNA of the parasite
  • • Staining of the parasite's DNA is accomplished by the dyes within Leishman stain, such as methylene blue and eosin, which bind to nucleic acids and proteins, highlighting the parasite structures. Methanol’s role is purely in the fixation process and does not contribute directly to the staining of DNA.
  • • Option C. Enhances the visibility of parasites
  • • Option C. Enhances the visibility of parasites
  • • The enhancement of parasite visibility is mainly due to the contrasting action of the stains, which differentially color the parasites and cellular components, making them more visible. Methanol does not enhance visibility but ensures that the structures remain attached to the slide during staining.
  • • Option D. Prevents red blood cell hemolysis
  • • Option D. Prevents red blood cell hemolysis
  • • Methanol does not specifically prevent hemolysis of red blood cells; rather, it fixes the cells to the slide to preserve their morphology. Hemolysis prevention is more reliant on careful sample handling and the staining technique rather than the fixative used.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acetone-free methanol in Leishman's stain serves primarily to fix cells to the slide, preserving their morphology by stabilizing cellular proteins and adhering them firmly to the surface. This fixation step is critical to maintain the integrity of blood smears during staining, allowing accurate microscopic identification of cellular components and parasites such as Leishmania.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with the blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease, a specific form of diabetic nephropathy, is characterized by PAS-positive nodules within the glomeruli, often associated with type 1 diabetes mellitus.
  • ➤ Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8 th edition, Page No. 2206
  • ➤ Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8 th edition, Page No. 2206

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child presented with fever, fatigue and left ventricular dysfunction. He underwent a cardiac biopsy (image shown). Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lymphocytic myocarditis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lymphocytic myocarditis is indicated by the presence of lymphocytic infiltration in the myocardium and is commonly associated with viral infections. The clinical presentation includes heart failure symptoms, fever, and fatigue.

questions.text: Gamma delta T cell receptors (γδ TCRs) recognizes? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gamma delta T cell receptors (γδ TCRs) are unique in that they can recognize lipids and other molecules without the need for MHC protein presentation , distinguishing them from the more common αβ T cells.
  • ➤ Gamma delta T cell receptors (γδ TCRs)
  • ➤ lipids and other molecules without the need for MHC protein presentation
  • ➤ Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 353
  • ➤ Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 353

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with anemia and hemoglobinuria. Investigations reveal increased lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). The peripheral smear image is given below. Which of the following physical examination findings can support the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mechanical second heart sound

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient presenting with anemia, hemoglobinuria, increased LDH, and schistocytes on a peripheral smear, the presence of a mechanical second heart sound can support the diagnosis of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA) due to mechanical heart valves. The mechanical destruction of red blood cells leads to intravascular hemolysis, characteristic laboratory findings, and specific physical examination findings related to the heart valve.

questions.text: Which of the statements below accurately pertain to amyloidosis? ( INICET MAY 2023) It is an extracellular protein. It is called amyloid because of starch like deposition. Beta-pleated sheets are seen on X-ray crystallography AL is a secondary type of amyloidosis.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 4-year-old patient presented with a rectal mass 2.5 cm by 3 cm. On biopsy it had the presence of colonic mucosa with multiple dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory cells. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hamartoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A rectal mass in a young child with biopsy findings of colonic mucosa and multiple dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory cells is indicative of a juvenile polyp, which is a type of hamartomatous polyp.

questions.text: The image below shows simple muscle twitch along with the time trace, recorded in a frog gastrocnemius muscle. Calculate the minimum tetanizing frequency. (The time tracer was made with a 100hz tuning fork)?(INICET 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 20 per second

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The minimum tetanizing frequency of a muscle is determined by the reciprocal of the contraction period.
